awd_titl_txt: Cohort Community for Academic Achievement Persistence and Perseverance in STEM Scholars Program
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project will increase the number of students, who major in STEM disciplines at Albany State University and go on to successfully pursue STEM post-graduate education or research careers.  During the project, 18 scholars will (a) develop and follow a four-year academic and professional plan that will include freshman learning community courses, workshops, service learning, and field trips or visitations under the guidance of a Student Success Coach, (b) participate in at least one undergraduate research experience, and (c) attend and present an undergraduate research project at an on-campus or regional conference. After graduation these talented scholars are expected to join the STEM workforce or go on to graduate school in STEM, enabling the US to compete and innovate in a global economy. 

The theory of action for this project is that psychosocial factors such as STEM identity and self-efficacy are particularly critical to retaining STEM students.  Thus, the project elements are designed to help students to develop these factors through a strong cohort anchored around a freshman learning community, targeted and intrusive advising, mentoring by faculty and peers, and participation in undergraduate research and internships.  Evaluation will address the project's success in achieving its retention, course pass rate, and graduation objectives.   Data analysis of student academic performance and participation in program activities will be used to study the effects of interventions like the learning community and intrusive advising on self-efficacy and science identity for students at a Historically Black University.  The research results will be disseminated at the University System of GA Teaching and Learning Conference and the Understanding Interventions that Broaden Participation in STEM Careers conference.  Manuscripts will be submitted to the Journal of Higher Education and the Journal of College Science Teaching.

por.por_cntn:
The CAPS2 program aimed to support eighteen freshmen with a GPA of 3.0 or higher and majoring in biology, chemistry, computer science or mathematics with scholarships of up to $7500 per year based on academic talent and financial need. Two cohorts of 9 first-year students were recruited into the program in Fall 2016 and 2017.  Eighteen scholars were targeted; however, due to transfers and those dismissed for academic reasons, a total of 28 scholars were supported.

The specific objectives are

Objective 1: The Project will maintain a Scholars? retention rate of 80%.

Objective 2:  Scholars will maintain a first-attempt passing rate of 80-90% in seven (7) gate-keeping courses (College Algebra, Pre-Calculus, Calculus, Physics, General Biology, General Chemistry, and Organic Chemistry).

Objective 3:  STEM Scholars will maintain a BS graduation rate of 80%.

Objective 4:  The Project will maintain an 85% placement rate of graduating Scholars in full-time employment in their STEM field or in graduate or professional school within six months of graduation.

Objective 5: The SSTEM Scholars Program will maintain a record of publications resulting from Albany State University's quasi-experimental testing of support strategies to address academic and professional barriers STEM students face.

Activities of the project included biweekly meetings, STEM seminar series attendance, peer mentoring, success coaching sessions, and participation in undergraduate research on or off-campus. Mentoring opportunities occurred during meetings with project faculty in one-on-one sessions, bi-weekly meetings, and success coaching sessions. Students attended a minimum of two success coaching sessions each semester. A requirement of scholars at the beginning of coaching sessions was the development of a Success Plan to assist students in four key areas; academic performance, social growth, career development, and personal health/wellness. In addition to workshops on various topics, the bi-weekly meetings provided opportunities for group discussions, where alumni and the more experienced cohort group could share information. These included sessions on success strategies, navigating institutional barriers, opportunities for integration into the university community, STEM careers, summer internships, and graduate school selection and application. Students overwhelmingly indicated that the biweekly meetings and the success coach sessions were the most helpful to them. The success coaching sessions were required at least twice per semester for the scholars and included. 

The program retained nineteen of the twenty-eight scholars supported (67.8%). Of the 32% percent that were not retained, five transferred to other institutions; three were dismissed due to lack of academic progress and one student lost financial eligibility. Throughout the program, scholars? performance in targeted gatekeeping courses was above overall pass rates in these courses, with over 80% of Scholars passing gate-keeping and advanced courses in biology, chemistry, and mathematics with grades of B. This satisfied objective two of the project. Of the nineteen students retained in the program, eleven entered the program as freshmen, and all eleven (100%) completed their degrees in 4 years. It is noteworthy, for example, that one Scholar, who entered the program as a freshman, graduated with a dual major in Chemistry and Forensic Science and another Scholar completed his degree in 3.5 years. Achievements such as these underscore the importance of assuring that Scholars have support and mentorship from their entry as freshmen through graduation.

Overall the 4 -year graduation rate of Scholars who were retained in the program is 78.9%. The 6-year graduation rate for the program is 100%. Both rates are significantly higher than the institution?s 4 and 6-year graduation rates, which are 11% and 35%, respectively. Fourteen of the 19 retained scholars have been placed in STEM jobs or graduate school in STEM disciplines within one year of graduation. A key achievement of the program is that a significant number of these scholars (nine) have gone to graduate school in biology, chemistry, chemical engineering, and mathematical sciences. Though clinical professions are not a component of the SSTEM program, four additional scholars entered medical and nursing professional schools. While not a goal of SSTEM, it should be noted that the project's activities were also essential to these students' success.

Scholars' exposure to research participation in internal and external research internships undoubtedly facilitated their interest and enrollment in graduate school. Seventy-eight percent of scholars participated in a summer research internship. Despite the pandemic, a few scholars participated in multiple internships. 

 The project contributed to broadening the participation of underrepresented students in STEM careers. Participants' responses in surveys and focus groups were favorable to the project, and the project has a record of completers' success. While we did not meet all targeted benchmarks for the project, the project was able to support 28 scholars, more than the targeted number of 18 scholars, and nineteen of these were retained. The employment of Scholars, some before graduation, and Scholars' competitiveness for graduate and professional school admission and employment in their STEM fields testify to the project's quality and effectiveness. 

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2022
Modified by: Louise V Wrensford
